title: It's like i7-8700 But with 10% lower frequency, for Half Price!! xD
content: Lets make this short as possible..Ryzen 5 - 2600 Is:  6 Cores & 12 Threads boost to 3.9 (single core) While  all cores are 3.7GHzIntel i7 - 8700 is:  6 Cores & 12 Threads boost to 4.6 GHz (single core) While all cores are all cores 4.3GHzBut still, you can OC with like $20 after market cooler and turbo all cores to 4.0 GHz instead of 3.7GHzThe cooler came with it, is an ok (reached 75c in stress test)  But in games it's reaching 60cLast Note:AMD not only have super value CPUs..But also have Super value MotherboardsWhy?B450 for example is $70 to $130 but support 1st Ryzen Gen, Second Ryzen Gen, and Third Ryzen Gen (probably even 4th Ryzen Gen)In other other hand, all Intel Motherboards (Z170, Z270, Z370) are supporting 2 Generations onlySo yeah, you Pay like $200 for Ryzen CPU + $100 Mobo  ($300 total)While Intel you pay $350 to $400 for CPU + $150 Mobo  ($500 to $550 total)Hope that clear up your mind xD
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: Top notch, AMD is back!
content: I upgraded from an AMD FX-8320 to this.  I knew it would be better.  I didn't know how much better though!I built a system around this with a m.2 NVMe PCI SSD, 16GB 3200GB RAM, PNY Nvidia 1060 6GB GTX, and Asus x470 motherboard.This thing is an incredible CPU for the midrange.  VR works extremely well on it, it overclocks easily, and comes with a very good cooler with decent thermal paste so you save $50 or more right there!  Flies through my normal workloads which include web browsing, virtual machines, VR, gaming and file serving.I am not sure you could get a better performer for the money than this CPU.  5+ stars!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Cool, fast and quiet. Great value.
content: This was an upgrade from FX6300 CPU. I primarily play WoW and use Lightroom with my photography. I have often stayed a bit behind with performance and have finally caught up! For the first time ever, I have consistently solid framerates in games and a much less laggy photo processing experience. The cooler is fantastic. The quietest cpu fan I've ever had, and the cpu itself stays surprisingly cool (between 40 and 50c). My ONLY point of frustration came from some instability (random, long system freezes) I experienced that took me a while to troubleshoot, first thinking it was probably some sort of memory incompatibility. It ended up being an incompatibility with the Windows 10 Ryzen power plan that was installed. Switched to the regular "Performance" plan and its been rock solid ever since. I hope having that tidbit here helps save someone else the hassle.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: Upgrading from a 10 year old PC
content: Upgrading from a 10 year old PC which was a 2.20 Gz Dual-Core HP Pavilion to my first custom PC using this CPU as the center piece. It comes without saying that I was no longer being shackled down by the limitation of my old PC with my work flow and also the games I play multitasking with no issues. It's teamed up with an MSI Radeon RX 560 AERO ITX 4G OC128-bit 4GB graphic card.There's tons of tests on how well this CPU performs with games especially mainstream games that I do not need to go into as I'm more into video stuff so watching YouTube videos in 1080p is something else coming from 480p tho without realizing it I still find myself watching in 480p at times. Old habits. Watching 1080p HEVC videos with no lag is again something else to behold, heck, Ryzen 5 2600 isn't on his final form yet with that stuff. [Edit Oct 2020] Viewing 4K YouTube videos is also no issues either. Exceptions of course is based on your internet speed's capacity to buffer fast. Not sure about watching in 4K HEVC video tho since my monitor is only 1080p.[Edit Oct 25, 2020] Video encoding can take 30 min to 10 hours depending on the length, resolution, and which chroma sampling profile is being used, any filters will add to the encoding time. A 24 min clip with veryslow or placebo settings (with filters) are no problem speed-wise with H.264 10 bit encodes. From either 4:2:0 or 4:4:4 chroma sampling profile finishes it up quick with 18 thread encoding speed! This coming from almost an entire day's worth on my old PC's pitiful 3 threads using the same settings. Regular H.264 8 bit will use 15 threads as its max (if --thread=0 is used) and will obviously be much faster then its 10 bit counterpart. I recommend trying out tesa + subme 11 mode with either profiles if time isn't an issue.Not tested it with HEVC as of yet.[Edit - Oct 25, 2020] A few sample tests using HEVC 4:4:4 720p with veryslow and sea mode settings (no tune) of a 24 min clip took about 2-13 hours depending on the amount of filters being applied (such as heavy-duty filters like Anti-Aliasing) with max 12 numa-pools (it's kinda like --thread in H.264 but not really?) if left at its default.  The profile 8 bit, 10 bit, or 12 bit will either shorten or increase the time, However, the trade of will be higher quality such as more smoother gradients decreasing banding, color format (both at the cost of increased computation during playback) and of course the chroma sampling being used. Be mindful if your target is compatibility tho consult with the x265 documentation if interested especially with the release of HEVC 3.0 (GCC 8.3.0) which brings a number of changes such as the addition of the tune animation.To be noted all of this was done on a single Crucial 8GB DDR4 RAM which rarely hit 100% RAM output doing all of the above while encoding but I may add an additional 8/16 GB RAM in the future especially for any 1080p (and 4K) HEVC encodes, so you may want to increase your RAM if that's your target. Further note, if you watch streaming videos such as YouTube while waiting for your video to finish up be certain not to open so many browser tab. The RAM will increase closer to 100% if you've got just 8 GB, speaking from experience.I purchased this through the OutletPC seller and they were able to help me out on my concerns and questions as a first time CPU buyer though it wasn't the best of help it got the point across regarding the handling of the CPU and the chances of being a root cause when troubleshooting hardware issues getting the PC to boot properly.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 17, 2018

title: Nuclear Submarine
content: I recently purchased this processor for my new PC build and it's my first AMD CPU i've ever purchased. Right out of the box it screams class with solid packaging and includes a decent/stylish cooler.Using a B450 MSI Gaming Pro Carbon AC motherboard + Corsair H100i PRO AIO liquid cooling, I manage a stable overclock to 4.0GHz at 1.25V (could probably go even lower) and temps stay around 31 deg C at idle, and around 50 deg when gaming.To give you an idea of benchmarking, I did a benchmark with User Benchmark, and thanks to the combination of my overclock, MoBo and AIO, i got a 100% Score for Gaming (Nuclear Submarine), 91% Score for Desktop (Nuclear Submarine) and 87% Score for Workstation (Aircraft Carrier). My GPU is a GTX 1070 Seahawk X, and I'm using 16GB DDR4 3000MHz Corsair RAM.(The average scores for a Ryzen 5 2600 are 88% for Gaming, 85% for Desktop and 79% for Workstation)So it literally gives me such good value as it performs way above its class. I'm very happy with it. You will be too.

title: Initally felt ripped off, but AMD pulled through as always
content: The "feeling ripped off" part was complete user error mind you. I somehow disabled or didn't turn on "Multithreading" for this after installing and setting up the new PC. Task manager was showing six cores, as it should, and I didnt question it. However after the recent month of playing newer games and them all being absolute CPU hogs, I started looking into why this CPU was performing worse than the FX 8350 I upgraded from. Long story short I downloaded AMD Ryzen Master (software used to monitor and/or overclock your AMD Ryzen Chips), noticed the "multithreading" option was turned on without realizing at the time it was off before, check Task Manager again and boom, suddenly my PC is running on 12 cores (6 cores, 6 threads)I was bewildered. Simply by downloading this program, I damn near double the potential power of the CPU.I didnt stop there though. The base speed is 3.4GHz with the BIOS automatically overclocking it to about 3.7GHz.I turned off the auto overclock through Ryzen Master and did it myself.With a Corsair H60 CPU cooler, 1.4V, I can safely run stress tests for several minutes at 4.2GHz.I could probably go higher but I am now absolutely in love with this CPU and want it to last as long as possible.Also there is literally no need for me to go higher. Streaming and gaming at the same time, even at slow encoding speeds, I never break 80% CPU load or 70 degrees Celcius.So note to new builder, make sure you enable multithreading. And if you aren't sure, just get the AMD Ryzen Master program and it will make sure it's on for you.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 16, 2018

title: CPU is great, heatsink needs work! (also package fail!)
content: The CPU itself is great!  I'm glad that AMD is finally starting to make a comeback (I haven't used AMD CPUs before this since the heyday of the Athlon64 x2!).  Six cores handles gaming and multitasking like a champ, and runs nice and cool.The heatsink, however, was a HUGE pain in the ass to install!  The thermal paste it came with was contaminated by debris (possibly due to damaged packaging) so I had to strip it off and supply my own thermal paste, and screwing this heatsink down onto the motherboard was exceedingly difficult (and I work on Cisco UCS blades!).  AMD needs to rethink their heatsink designs and go back to the clamping kind of heatsink.  Once installed, this cooler does well, but just installing it is a nightmare!

title: Not the bleeding edge, but great for 99.9% of tasks
content: I just used this processor to upgrade one of my daughters' PCs to a spec capable of running a high-end VR headset.  It replaced a 3-core AMD APU.There's a wide range of Ryzen CPUs.  They have varying numbers of cores, some support hyperthreading, some don't, some have integrated RadeonHD graphics, some don't.  You can pretty easily find sites online that will tell you how to decode AMD's Ryzen model numbers to make sense of what's what.This processor, the Ryzen 5 2600, has 6 cores at 3.9GHz that can run up to 12 simultaneous threads, but no integrated graphics.  That's fine if you want to use it with a separate graphics card, and 6 cores should be plenty for almost any normal workload.  It requires a Socket 4 motherboard.  It's a pretty good middle-of-the-road price point ‚Äî good performance for almost any task, but not up to the point where your credit card flees screaming at the mention of its name and extreme gamers offer to duel you for possession of it.So there you go.  Proven AMD architecture, good bang for the buck, and comes with an almost-dead-silent CPU cooler.  Unless you're a celebrity gamer with an online handle that causes lacerations at 30 feet (or at least, want to be one), what more do you need?
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2018

title: Awesome Value! Check Motherboard BIOS compatibility before installing
content: I replaced a 10 year old Core 2 Duo based system with a rig that sports the Ryzen 5 2600 at its core. After reading reviews, benchmark data, power usage data, etc. I decided I would finally give AMD a try. I used to shy away from AMD because there wouldn't be enough of a price differential in AMD's favor to justify moving to AMD. I have no regrets replacing my media server with this solution and here's why:* Power: Six cores and 65W rating means the purchase price alone will be offset by power savings in the first 18-24 months.* Speed: Six cores x 3.4GHz processing speed will drastically reduce the time to transcode videos and increase the number of clients I can support with my Plex server, while serving up all the other services I run on the box.* Value: Six cores from the competitor will run about $100 more for the CPU alone. Add the extra 30W (95W TDP vs. 65W TDP) and the power bill for the competitor equivalent will be about 35-45% higher. I also read somewhere that AMD hasn't been changing the socket requirements and forcing users to buy new motherboards with subsequent processor generations, which is yet another plus as long as this holds true (and is technically feasible).The only word of caution I have is this: If you're performing a new build and don't have any older AM4 CPUs lying around, I highly recommend checking your potential choice of motherboard for processor compatibility prior to ordering. I chose a B350 board and had to get a boot kit from AMD to facilitate a BIOS update to make this CPU work with it. This oversight cost me more time and hassle since I was unwilling to seek out or pay for alternative solutions to my issue. In the future, I'll be sure to check the vendors' support sites and make sure I buy a motherboard that supports the CPU from its "Base" BIOS version.My only complaint is that the hold-down screws for the heatsink have too much spring tension, which makes threading into the backing plate a bit challenging. I also ended up rotating the fan 90 degrees on the heatsink so that the logo would not obstruct the DIMM slot. I could have oriented the cooler's logo over the heatsink on the opposite side by rotating the cooler 180 degrees instead but felt it was worth the effort to "fool-proof" myself.I have a 3rd generation i7-based PC that I will more than likely replace with the AMD Ryzen 5 in the near future. In fact, I look forward to it.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2018

title: Best CPUs for cost-to-perfomance and Gaming
content: I purchased the Ryzen 5 2600 for my sons gaming build. I personally own the Ryzen 5 3600 in my gaming machine and knew that these Ryzen CPU's are hands down the best CPU's on the market... Many may disagree with this statement but let me explain why.Price:Ryzen CPU's are priced much lower than Intel counterparts and offer a better price/performance. Pairing a Ryzen 5 2600 with a AM4 motherboard is much less than the equivalent pairing of a Intel I5-8400 with a 1151 socket. $120 for a Ryzen 52600 or $245 for the Intel equivalent.. i'm sure you can do that math.Performance:While the I5 mentioned above technically is slightly faster in single and quad core operations, the Ryzen 5 smokes the Intel I5 due to it's hexacore configuration. Pair this with a decent overclock and you have a capable processor that comes in at half the price of the competition.The Ryzen series cpu's like a good fast ram. There are plenty of options to choose from here on Amazon but I personally went with the Patriot Viper 4 16GB (8x2) 3200 Mhz ram - https://amzn.to/31vUnPi and have not regretted this purchase one bit.Future Proof:With every few iterations of the Intel CPU's comes a new chip set and corresponding board configuration. The Ryzen series processors (Now Gen 4) are all compatible with the AM4 socket. Not only does this make building your rig easy, but there is some assurance that when you want to upgrade to the latest Ryzen CPU you will not have to buy a new board and possibly ram on top of it. Most upgrades I have seen consist of a newer gen processor and a motherboard firmware update.I am not a AMD fanboy and do enjoy seeing the performance and specs coming from the Intel processors. Saying this, I do know how to spot deals and at sub $130 this CPU is an absolute monster.Recommended pairingsPatriot Viper 4 16GB (8x2) 3200 Mhz DDR4 ram - https://amzn.to/31vUnPiMSI B450 Gaming Plus Max Motherboard: https://amzn.to/2UtQF7mAMD Ryzen 5 2600 Processor - https://amzn.to/39cvPO9Thanks for reading, hopefully my review helped provide information towards your purchase.Happy Gaming!As an amazon associate I earn from qualifying purchases.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018

title: Build your own.
content: Like the title says.  Build your own.  Why, you ask?  Very simple and I'll give you a very good example.  I had an Intel Core i5 chip on an intel Motherboard.  I've always built my own and I built that one in 2010.  With age and some other factors thrown in it started to perform very poorly.  So, feeling lazy I ordered an already to go refurbished HP Elite Desk 800 G3 with a core i7 in it.  I like to game a little (truth) and I figured I would add my pci-e video card to it and be good to go.  Not so fast, my friend.  HP's motherboards, power supplies, and cases are all propietary.  What that means is.....no upgrades unless you want to put up a serious fight and do some hours long series of modifications on the power supply to get it to work.  So, sent it back and ordered the AMD Ryzen 5, 16 Gig of DDR4 RAM, and a Asus Motherboard.  Used my old case, power supply, hard drive, video card, etc and put it together in an hour and had it up and running in two.  $400 out the door and I couldn't be happier with its performance.  I'll update on gaming performance in the next few weeks and give a final verdict then, but it seems pretty good so far.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 11, 2019

title: Eh
content: I bought this to upgrade my Intel I5 4570 (which i use with Asrock z87 Extream4 and 8GB ram)). Bought this as well as an Asrock Fata1ity x470 (Which by the way is terrible and nothing but problems and Bios is ugly and pathetic)  and 16GB ram.Now I don't know what the problem was (see Asrock above) but there was no perceivable difference (speed or otherwise) from this Ryzen 5 2600 cpu then my ooooold i5 4570. I was totally NOT impressed and disappointed. After fighting with and dealing with Asrock motherboard (which was even a bigger disappointment as I use to love Asrock but never again as they have dropped the ball and sunk to VERY low end. even their mid-high end acts like low end with their awful Bios). So after I finally get Asrock board working correctly, I was stunned at how little improvement there really was from my old cpu. Not a whole lot different and defiantly not worth the $ to improvement ratio. Sent it all back. I really really wanted Ryzen to be a great upgrade but it was just not. I do think though that if I can find a better Motherboard, Ryzen has a better upgrade path and more future proof then Intel. With Ryzen Motherboard's you can at least upgrade to several higher Ryzen CPU's before having to upgrade the whole system(like Intel). So I'll probably stick with Ryzen but wait in till I can afford a higher Ryzen cpu then a 2600. Sent it all back for now though as there was little difference between what I have now and this Ryzen 2600.

title: Beast for money, our go-to CPU choice these days.
content: Amazing value and truly more PC than most useslrs ever actually need or have a use for.  Loves fast RAM, 3000Mhz minimum in my opinion and 3200Mhz is tits.  It'll run much faster RAM like the 3600Mhz and some 4k chips, but I didn't notice a value increase worth spending money for the faster RAM and I get better multi-tasking it seems by using that money to add more GBs of 3k or 3200Mhz.  We have 3 Ryzens in our home office, an R7 2700 and (2) R5 2600's.  Two are running 32GBs of Corsair 3000 and 1 is running 16GBs of 3200 and all run anything we throw at them.  The 2600's do everything we need and the only reason for the (1) 2700 was because of the amount of multi-tasking workload that it's used for simultaneously... But I will say that it's not the normal usage most people will throw at their PC.  When people ask me about the PC's that I build for daytraders and then start talking about their need for the fastest CPU around usually they don't realize that they're willing to blow all their money on the chip and then bottleneck themselves by cheaping out on everything else.  Skip the stupidity and marketing BS.  These are beastly chips that handle massive amounts of workload very quickly... Spend the money to get a motherboard, RAM, Drives, and GPU card that match your needs and expectations because when you eliminate bottlenecks you get an amazing value and a stellar PC.  Also, don't neglect a good case with proper airflow because heat kills electronics.  Water cooling is not needed and a good down-firing cooling fan such as the included one or even an upgraded one is all that you need, they also help you to keep the VRMs and other critical components cooled unlike when you choose the water cooling route.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 15, 2018

title: Fantastic value and performance

I have this paired with an RX580 GPU and 16gb or ddr4 3000mhz ram. Intel's I5 8400 is probably it's closest competition but the Ryzen 5 2600 clearly beats it in my opinion with the multitasking potential of this CPU. The stock cooler will get the job done but if you want to overclock it (I have no need at the time to do that) I'd invest in a better cooler or get the 2600x version

title: So good I bought it twice.
content: Bought one of these for what used to be my main rig, and another for a secondary mini-itx build, not sure which one is which anymore though.GREAT processor, all the cores/threads allow me to have a bunch of stuff open at the same time with no hiccups. Most Ryzen chips won't OC well so you probably don't need an aftermarket cooler anyways if your case has good airflow.If you want to run CPU intensive programs smoother you will need fast RAM. title: Heart of My Workhorse of a Computer Build For Under $900
content: As the title says, I built a beast of a computer for under $900...that's everything including the Windows License.I use Presonus StudioOne 4 Pro and Notion 6. I have an overclocked Ryzen 7 1700 in my studio. I decided to build a "budget" computer for my living room with this processor for editing, mixing, and mastering, so that I could do this tedious process out with my family and be a little more social.I am very happy with my decision to use this processor. I chose to go with stock cooling and not overclock this one. I paired in with my RX570 and 16mb of 2400 RAM.It has handled everything I have thrown at it without barely breaking 100 degrees Fahrenheit. The max I have thrown at so far is probably about 20 digital tracks and roughly 6 more analog tracks with many layers of effects. I use a lot of high resource VST plug ins, such as Melodyne and Kontakt.At first I was trying to get by on my "budget" build with 8GB of RAM. This was causing problems when I had 12 or more tracks going, but after I upgraded to 16gb, I have had no problems at all.I notice only a nominal difference between my 2 computers in regards to rendering time. I am not a "hardcore" gamer, but the games I do play, such as Starcraft 2, play very smooth at max settings with the R7 570.Bottom line is that you can  have an incredibly powerful computer without spending over $900 total easily, with this CPU at the heart of it. And I really like the future of the AM4 socket, as upgrading will hopefully be real easy if that is ever even needed.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018

title: Can't think of a single other chip at this pricepoint that rivals it
content: I absolutely love this CPU.  Well done AMD!  It comes with an included cooler which is super easy to install and has pre-applied thermal paste (which considering you won't be overclocking this it just means you're saving that much more money on your build).  Great performance, and now enough time has passed where Ryzen Drivers are actually super stable.  Some would argue "get the Ryzen 5 2600X, because it is only $16 more and has a higher base clock with a better cooler". However, I would argue that $16 for an extremely small bump in performance could be set aside into getting an upgraded SSD, or put towards an upgrade in GPU, which would carry more impact. That having been said, Ryzen unlocked all their chipsets to be overclockable, so you're really paying $16 more for a better cooler, and a chip they claim is better at overclocking.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2019

title: Best price for the performance.
content: I got this for around $160, and I love it. Although I have to say that it is my first pc build, it came out great. I little problem with it. The only problem was mounting that fan that comes with it. I don‚Äôt know if that‚Äôs the problem with the motherboard or the fan. The fan is very hard to install due to the springs. You have to slowly screw in each screw one at a time, little by little, and if you mess up even slightly, you start to break the board and the screw. Other than that, this is a great CPU. I paired it with a GTX 1060 and it runs games on high generally above 100 FPS. Although AMD CPUs, especialy the Ryzen line ones, are not the best at running games, they definitely give you the best price for preformance. Just make sure to do the bios and other updates, my mouse was not compatible until I did.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 6, 2018

title: very good CPU, terrible cooling
content: I'm not sure why I did this, but when I was assembling my new computer I was feeling grouchy about thermal paste and told myself that surely AMD is selling adequate cooling for their products when used at the stock settings they were designed for.  I wasn't going to overclock so the product they are selling should work.  ...... Wrong.  I don't know why I trusted AMD, but it was absolutely the wrong call.  I powered up my computer and noted in the bios it was running hotter than I expected.  After installing windows and Steam, I finally tested it with a game released in 2012.  FAIL.  The CPU, with AMD's supplied thermal compound and cooling fan, immediately hit max temperature.really I shot myself in the foot by putting any trust in them.  I had to power down so I could disassemble, take off the cooling fan, and applied 2019 arctic silver paste.  With real thermal paste applied the CPU is now within acceptable range when gaming, but it's still a tad on the high side.  My next step if I want to reduce this would be to buy and install a different CPU cooler.Second note: the CPU cooler was awful to install. It has spring mounted screws that don't drop into the holes so it was very difficult to line up and screw in.Still, this is a great amount of processing power for the money.  Just be aware that you must also buy thermal paste, rubbing alcohol (to remove the original crap paste), and a good CPU cooler even if the only use will be at settings AMD designed and sold it for.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 27, 2019

title: AMD Stepped Up Their Game
content: Friends of mine urged me to go with Intel due to it being better for gaming, but I'm glad I went with AMD for my build. Paired with an RTX 2060, I have had no problem running games at 1440p 60fps+ at ultra settings.The Wraith cooler is a great bonus, though I swapped mine with an ARCTIC Freezer 34 eSports Duo. With this set up, the CPU stays cool around 45c at full load.I was able to OC this CPU to 4.0GHz @ 1.3125v. I decided against a constant OC as the XFR2 was boosting to 3.9-4.1GHz on demand.If you're looking for an excellent budget CPU for gaming, this is as good as it gets.Tip: If you're looking to OC, use the Ryzen Master software to test stability before committing the changes to your BIOS.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: Really great engine for my new computer
content: My old computer was about 10 years old and I had to do something before they stop supporting Windows 7 in January.  I decided to try building a new system and after choosing the GIGABYTE X470 AORUS ULTRA GAMING motherboard I then chose this AMD chip to go with it.I got great prices for both on Amazon Prime Day and after four months of usage, I'm extremely pleased with my purchase.  The computer runs super fast with Windows 10 Pro and I've had no problems at all with any aspect of the computer's operation.  The computer starts up and is ready to use in less than a minute and I haven't noticed even the slightest bit of lag in anything that I've asked it to do.Hopefully I'll get a good 10 years out of this like I did with my last AMD chip.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Intel has a Fight on it's Hands with AMD's Ryzen CPUs and Included Fans
content: Nice to see AMD is back in the CPU fight.  Great bang for the buck.  Only thing is that is is the second generation of the first Ryzen chip set.  Expect Ryzen 2 out soon - within a year or so of this writing.  And not all "AMD Ryzen Desktop 2000 Ready" motherboards are, or if they are, you need to update the BIOS first.  The only thing that is both a pro and a con is the thermal paste on the included fan.  It is already on the fan heat sink, and so it is easy to get your fingers in it if you don't expect it.  It also means you don't have to worry if you got enough of the stuff on the CPU, and if it is spread properly.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 11, 2019

title: AMD is making great strides
content: For the price point, the performance on this new issue of cpu is beyond amazing. Set up a gaming computer with a 290X AMD based card, just whips through games that would crash. With the 19meg of onboard cpu memory, you can see the difference on raw performance. I highly recommend this component for windows gaming.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 26, 2019

title: works fine-ish
content: so i got this cpu and was excited to move up from a 8350 which yes was a big move up. but sadly i had some mobo issues and ended up buying yet another mobo which is ok. now still to this day almost a year later after swapping many differn't parts i am pretty sure the criminal is this cpu . i can't OC my ram i have two seperate kits and both are on the list of compatability with this mobo ect. but for some reason they won't accept any OC even though they came rated for it. so this issue is this . the OC worked for like a month no problems and one day stopped working caused the system to be unstable so i checked the ram , system says rams fine which is cool. so i buy another kit does the same exact thing system becomes unstable won't even reach the boot screen again check this set all is green works fine. so now i have swapped ram and motherboard and gpu and power supply.... and hdd's and ssd's and several differn't installs of windows heck i even updated my mobo drivers.. so now it looks like its related to the cpu the last unreplaced part in this rig. only reason i would consider it is due to the fact that ryzen has a direct link to ram performance which leads me to think something is wrong with it boots just fine ect. but every now and again ill go to boot or restart my pc and i won't get my bios beep telling me everything is talking and working right so i am thinking the cpu might be faulty...but otherwise besides that it works fine so long as i don't attempt to OC ram which is sad because ryzen performance is directly link to just that ram speed. so i am missing out on performance which sucks...
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 18, 2018

title: Great Reputation for a Reason
content: I've had this CPU installed in my rig for the last few months and it's been great. No regrets whatsoever. Make no mistake, this is an exceptional CPU for the value and has a great reputation for running games well. There is a reason that most of the YouTube build recommendations, specifically for the budget-oriented, will suggest this CPU for your build. Intel should take a page from AMDs book because this card surpasses anything Intel offers at a similar cost; I might even say it surpasses some of what Intel offers at a significantly greater cost.In terms of quality, stability, performance I've had no issues. I use this computer for gaming, as well as overall work/research needs. I've been able to run several modern games without any issue (along with RX570 and 16GB DDR4/3000Mhz ram). With regards to work performance, I do a lot of bioinformatic analysis and this CPU has being able to run computationally demanding software/functions via OmicsBox and various scripts in R. Some of the data files that I've used have maybe 40,000 rows of data, all with multiple columns; I've been able to open, edit without any issues. Keep in mind that this is dependent on your ram and drive too!Overclocking? I've got this card up to 3.9Ghz with the stock AMD cooler on a B450M Aorus board. I've done stress testing with this clock and it's been totally stable. I've yet to experience a single crash with this OC. Some individuals have gotten their cards up to 4.1 or 4.2 even I think...but, this is contingent on the strength of your individual card. There is some variability in the OC potential from card to card. But, I'd say most can reasonably achieve 3.9 without issue. I plan to liquid cool this CPU in the next week and will see how that affects things. Temperatures have been a little high at times, but again I'm using a stock cooler with a decent OC, often playing highly demanding games.I'd highly recommend this card to budget and maybe even non-budget minded individuals. This is a great CPU and I'd probably put more money into a better GPU before I even thought about upgrading this.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 30, 2018

title: OC + Arctic Freezer Rev.2, better value over X version
content: The short of it: For the cost of the X version, you can buy this and a ARCTIC Freezer Xtreme Rev. 2 or a Cooler Master Hyper 212 Evo and get a higher and consistent all cores speed. 4Ghz @ 1.35v is safe and drama free.In depth: This CPU clocked up to 4Ghz will run at a base of 3.8Ghz and all cores will boost up to 4Ghz. The stock X version will only run a base of 3.6Ghz and some cores can briefly boost up to 4.2Ghz as it is held back by it's stock clock, Spire cooler and cheap thermal grease. The 212 Evo/Freezer Rev.2 comes with better pre-applied paste so you won't have to buy separate grease. Now you could get the X version of this, and upgrade to cooler... however at that point your total cost would exceed the Ryzen 7 2700. The X version doesn't make sense.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 19, 2019

title: Best thing I've seen in years.
content: I am a software developer who hates upgrading his hardware, but when I saw the price on this CPU, I knew I had to get one right away.  Bought a B450 motherboard and this processor for a wonderfully low price and set it up with Windows 10 Pro.  Installed without a hitch and runs very fast and quiet.  I don't game, but for everything else the Ryzen 5 2600 has been rock solid so call me an extremely happy customer.  The upgrade path lookseasy as prices keep falling it should be a matter of simply socketing a new and even faster Ryzen chip, but I don't expect to be doing this for some years.Best buy a fast SSD with this CPU as you will not get the full speed effect if you're using a mechanical drive.  Bravo AMD!
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 25, 2020

title: Budget CPU King üëë
content: I was looking to replace my Intel i5 3570k, motherboard, & RAM with the best setup for $400. I snagged the Ryzen 5 2600, the ASUS ROG Strix B450 Motherboard, & 16GB of DDR4, which put me right at $400 before taxes.Render times and gaming are fantastic. Having 6-cores & 12 threads really helps with performance. I was going to get the Ryzen 2700 or 2700x, but the cost for the extra performance was too much. I think the Ryzen 5 2600 is the perfect price to performance CPU for most people. The Intel 8400 would end up costing more and would lose on multi-threaded applications, so for my purposes this CPU has been great. I can finally game & steam at 1440p144, although some games handle that better than others.The one thing that surprised me was how well the stock heatsink has performed. If you're only planning on light overclocking or none at all, this is not bad. I still haven't decided if I'm going to get the new Hyper 212 or go another route, but this is holding up fine so far.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2019

title: Only one problem
content: This is an upgrade to my old FX-6300 and a vast improvement. I use it primarily for video gaming and the performance in games like Total War: Warhammer 1&2 is markedly better. Load times, turn times, and frame rates are both very fast now and with the addition of an SSD and the recent turn times patch for WH2, it just flies through the turns! PC start up and shut down is also much faster.That said, while the performance of the CPU itself is fine the cooling unit isn't that great. I don't overclock or anything and my temps are fine but the thermal paste could be better and my fan was extremely noisy. I contacted Amazon about it and they sent me an entire new cooling unit free of charge, however, they initially wanted me to buy it and then they'd refund me half the cost of it. Sure, it was only like $12 but that's not the point and I told them I wasn't going to do that so they agreed to refund the full cost of the thing.I just installed the new fan today and it seems fine so far so I guess I just got a bad apple the first time.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 22, 2019

title: I would rate it higher, if I could
content: I have no idea how it is possible to produce a CPU and sell it for this price and have this level of performance.  I am using an ASUS Prime x470 mainboard and 16Gb 3200Mhz Gskill ram from the motherboard qvl list, with respective timings.  The CPU is running at stock settings and with the stock cooler.  I can do fluid 4K video editing with this setup and paid a fraction of what it would cost me to do a comparable intel setup.

title: Runs cool and silent.
content: Very easy to install.  The Amazon info mentioned thermal grease was enclosed, but I didn't find any tube.  There was a dab on the cooler, but I added more just to be safe.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: I've become and AMD fan - not the cooler type
content: I grew up with Intel, and I thought only communist would buy anything other than Intel.  About 7 months ago, I took a chance and built a really good dedicated graphics computer, using the AMD Ryzen 7 2700X (lots of cores and threads needed) on an ASUS Crosshair Hero MOBO and I am blown away with that for my videos, photo's and mucho rendering, etc.  So, when my 10 year old HP 3130 everyday computer started to groan (like the power supply is about to give up the ghost), I decided to build another workhorse, but with the AMD Ryzen 5 2600.  After finishing the build, I am pleased to report that I am just as happy with the Ryzen 5 as I am with the Ryzen 7, for what they are to do.  No, I am not a communist, but I am very happy with AMD and these CPU's.  The power to cost ratio on AMD vs Intel is significant, so if you are an Intel Die-Hard, maybe you should take a second look and a first chance on the AMD Ryzen 5 or 7 lineup.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2018

title: Best Value for Money!
content: This is one of the BEST value for money gaming and multi-tasking processors you can buy. This is a rock-solid CPU. I was able to easily push this one to 3.89GHz while staying cool (with the be quite! Dark Rock 4 cooler).Hit a Cinebench score of 1305.Six Cores, 12 threads. Niiiice!

title: From what I can tell.. It's great!
content: I'm not very smart when it comes to tech but I wanted to build my pc because I wanted a pink pc without paying an arm and a leg for someone else to build it. This CPU was recommended to me based on my budget and I am SO HAPPY I got it!All the tech stuff like overclocking and that I have no idea about but I can play a lot of games at 165 fps and watch youtube videos and Netflix fine so I'm set!BUT shortly after I bought this CPU for $120, AMD released another CPU (Ryzen 5 1600 AF) for only $85 and I think the same specs? So I recommend you check that out but I'm more than happy with what I purchased. 10/10, would recommend

title: Decent bang for your buck
content: Compared to the ryzen 3 2200g I had this is significantly better. Heck compared to the Intel core i5 7400 I had this is better. I have had no issues, that being said though they could have included a better cooler than the wraith stealth cooler because while you have some room for overclocking you can't go very high even with after market thermal paste.Edit 6-17-19 It may be the mobo i use but this has issues like occasionally it will crash windows so hard you dont even get a blue screen and if you are in the middle of an important report may as well kiss that goodbye because now its corrupted. What a joke.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2020

title: Would had been a great product. But, unfortunately, I received mine faulty.
content: As a product, the AMD Ryzen 5 2600 would had been easily most enthusiasts preferred CPU of choice versus Intel's. But as much as I would love to give this product a "perfect" rating for its amazing design, my actual experience with my purchase is not necessarily positive.I was compelled to buy this CPU back in Black Friday Sale due to the free shipping which significantly saved me money as an overseas consumer. While I was able to receive the product just fine and within a considerable timeframe, what I got is a dead CPU that requires returning. Initially, I asked for a replacement as I was seriously keen in building a new rig powered by an AMD Ryzen 5 2600 CPU. However, after making a follow-up to the status of the supposed replacement, I was informed that it was cancelled and that it is only eligible for a refund.Although I was refunded completely, including the shipping which was required for the returns, it had generated another expense which was not covered by the refund, namely having a qualified technician do necessary assessment about the computer I was building. Then, there is also the issue of the discrepancy in the value of exchange with my country's currency with that of the US Dollar which is basically lower than the time I made the purchase. The refund basically ended up less than the amount I originally paid for the item. Literally, I had just wasted my hard-earned money in this mishap.I just find it rather unfortunate having to go through so many disappointments in something that would have otherwise brought happiness to me. Right now, my rig is without a CPU to make it work which would therefore implore to just buy locally which substantially a lot more expensive than the current Amazon pricing.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 10, 2018

title: Fast purchase. Very happy
content: I bought this CPU as a replacement for a ryzen 5 3 600 as they were out of stock. I was very happy about the product arriving before the date it said it would. Faster shipping that I intended by about 24 hours. I intend to put this in my gaming rig I'm very pleased with my purchase and would buy again. Thank you Amazon for making this a very easy first purchase.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 12, 2019

title: Great value CPU!
content: For the money, this is a really hard processor to beat. I bought it to replace an Intel Quad-core processor which was about 10 years older and which cost nearly 3 times as much back then as this one did when I bought it a few weeks ago. I have it matched up with an MSI X570-a MB, and 32gb of DDR4 memory, and I'm glad I chose to go this way. This relatively inexpensive CPU is somewhat faster than my old Pentium I-7 on operations using a single CPU core. Where it really shines is multitasking. I do a lot of video recoding, and I am currently running two seperate recoding operations as well as email and web browsing, and haven't really seen any slowdown in any of them. If I had been on my old system, it would have slowed things down to point where the browsing and email would have been unusable, and the decoding times would have increased very substantially. Needless to say, I highly recommend this CPU. I am not a gamer, so the score on it is basically borrowed from other reviewers. Check those reviews if you want more specifics regarding gaming.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Ryzen is raisin-g above the competition
content: Excellent CPU for the price.Great for a gamer "Budget" build, it will handle all AAA modern games paired w/ a good CPU.I just built my Rig almost a month ago and couldnt be happier. Paired w/ a GTX 1070 SC, Auros B450M mobo and Vengeance LPX 3200mhz 2x 8GB ram (16 total) I am able to run all my favorite games (RDR2, Witcher 3, Warzone, Rainbow Six Siege, Fall Out 4 and 76 and WoW ) all on ultra or ultra/high settings at 60+ FPS no problem.I also heard this CPU is great for streaming and most work stations as well, definitely recommend it to anyone building their first rig or upgrading their current PC! Best of of all AMD is really out doing themselves and are making most of their Mobo's backwards compatible w/ this gen of cpu's and future cpu's!Edit- While I highly recommend this CPU, the 2600x is slightly better and only roughly $20 more so if u can afford maybe get the 2600x otherwise this gem will treat u well and do anything u ask of it!
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: First processor and it's blown me away!
content: The only issue that I've had has been the Wraith Spire cooler is a bit long at the top and covers RAM slot 1 on the MSI Tomahawk B450 Motherboard.I had to remove the cooler when I wanted to add more RAM, which resulted in a bit of breakdown and setup.Other than that, overclocking it has been easy and reliable, I've set it to 3.85ghz with no temperature issue with stock cooling on the CPU. No bottlenecking on anything that I've done or played, I don't know if I've even seen it get close to 80% in task manager while running so many programs.I bought it before the new releases, so it's a little cheaper now however I'm not too upset, as there was a promotion that was going on when buying AMD products. After doing a verification through AMD's website, I was given The Division 2 on UPLAY and World War Z & a DLC on the Epic Store. Both are $60 games, not including DLC so the CPU has basically paid for itself in game time with World War Z alone.Highly recommend, although now that the new processors are out... I'd say these should be the new low-budget standard over the 1600's, and of course the 2600x is only a little more for I believe 3.85ghz native.

title: Don't expect anything from promotional deals...

Their tech support said 5-6 days before the can get to you. Which I'm sure is after the promotion ends. Dissatisfied with the "deal" to say the least. It's a shame could have been way more stars...

title: Butter Smooooth!
content: First off, you need to be aware that this CPU does not have graphics support, so you will need to purchase a discrete graphics card, as the display ports on your motherboard will not function with this processor installed. If you want to use your motherboards on-board graphics, you'll need a different processor (Ryzen 5 2400G).I used this on a budget gaming build for my son (I'm not a gamer myself). Placed it on a Gigabyte B450 AORUS Pro WiFi, with 16GB RAM, 500GB M2 PCIe SSD, and an RX 580 GPU. Using the stock fan/heat-sink at stock clock speeds... it's butter smooth. I'm not talking about that hard stick of butter either... I'm talking about that smooooth creamy whipped butter!Stock fan and heat-sink are good, and look nice in my tempered glass case, so I have no plans to upgrade the cooling at this time. I understand that many have successfully overclocked this CPU using the stock cooling (which is great), but not sure my son would notice any significant real world difference in performance and/or get any additional enjoyment out of his game play, so I don't have any plans to overclock it at this time.If you're looking for a reasonably priced, capable processor and plan to use a discrete graphics card in your build... look no further.

title: Worth it üëå unless u can afford the Ryzen 7

I do not have the optional second fan installed on my 212 Evo.Specs:Ryzen 2600Hyper 212 Evo Black Edition16 gb Corsair Vengeance 3000 (xmp enabledEvga G2 80+gold 750 watt fully modular PSUMSI RX 580 8 gbMSI Tomahawk Mobo27 inch Ben Q Monitor 60hz o.c. to 75hzOverall I am very happy with this purchase and I definitely recommend it for a budget gaming rig. If I knew them what I know now I would have got the Ryzen 7 but for my first build in a long time this is perfect for 1080p gaming and light video editing.

title: AMD has won be back with the Ryzen 5 2600

title: Best Value for it's money

title: Check your power plan.. see if you have it on 'Ryzen Balanced Power Plan'
content: I ran 2 months unknowingly on the 'wrong' chipset drivers... windows updated everything and just gave it 'generic drivers'..If your running this AMD.. and some others.. and you dont have 'Ryzen Balanced power Plan' when checking your 'power options' on windows 10.. then you likely do not have the right chipset drivers for your PC.. even though everything says its up to date.. its not correct.. if you dont have that plan.. google the chipset drivers for amd 2600...other than that.. runs great..

title: Works exactly as expected
content: I'm using this CPU for a gaming/streaming computer that I built. This was the best CPU I could get for my motherboard. I've been buying AMD processors for 15 years and have not been disappointed about the value/price equation. I've been out of the market for a while but CLEARLY AMD has really stepped up their game. I had no intention to over clock this and it proved to be quite stable running Assassins Creed Odyssy for a few hours straight (with all of the Windows bloatwear  in the background). As with most CPU's today it came with it's own thermal grease precision applied (thank you AMD). Insertion into the motherboard didn't take much effort. I really wanted to get the 16 core MONSTER but in reality I don't have a need for it. I'm just a tech gear junkie like that. This is a great buy for average needs and I would totally buy it again.

content: My new AMD 5 2600 pc build is amazing.  It has plenty reserve horsepower to do anything I ask it to do.I have never seen my games run so smooth or beautiful as they do now being powered by this processor.As good as it is running now I don't think I will ever be needing to upgrade it; seriously.I'm very happy with my purchase of this AMD 5 2600 processor and happy how much money I saved by buying this one.To me this was a smart buy. content: runs every application and game i use with ease and performs as well as most i7 systems I have used for half the price - AMD is back and it feels good to have competition for big blue again.Highly recommend for gamers, productivity and even light media production.

title: Great CPU for the price - An excellent budget upgrade
content: So I upgraded from a 4 core i5-4690k and I"m seeing a huge difference in the speed of my computer. I'm getting great FPS on my games and games that ran poorly are now running amazingly. I paired this with 16GB DDR4 RAM and a 1070ti graphics card. It was very easy to install, but I didn't use the fan that came with it. I got a Corsair H55 AIO and that was easy to put on this. It keeps the CPU very cool and I was able to overclock it to 4.1Ghz. I highly recommend you pick this up if you're looking to upgrade from a 4 core CPU and want to save money.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Nothing but happiness
content: Disclaimer, I come from the land of corporate workstation Dells with i3 chips in them.  They are NOT fast.  Put this chip into an MSI B450 board with 16GB DDR4 3200 RAM and a decent SSD, and holy cow.  Everything is instant, it seems.  Really enjoying it.  Totally spoiled.  I want to replace every computer I touch now.  Great processor, excellent value.  If you won't be doing any gaming, get the Ryzen 3 with the graphics, but this Ryzen 5 2600 with a Sapphire RX580 is handling everything I've thrown at it without any hesitation so far.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 5, 2018

title: Good budget or stand in CPU
content: The Ryzen 5 2600 is probably the best value CPU on the market for low to midgrade gaming PCs. I was able to overclock mine to 4 GHz and though thats not spectacular, its pretty darn good for $100. This product screams value. Pair it with a GTX 1650 Super and you could have a cheap but worthy gaming PC for your time. As for me, I used this CPU as a stand in while I waited for the Ryzen 9 3950x to become available.My specs for this processor are ludicrous, but again, its a stand in for a R9 3950x.Ryzen 5 2600 @4 GHz 1.35VMSI Geforce GTX 1080 Gaming XMSI X570 Creation Motherboard16GB G.Skill Trident Z DDR4 3600 RAM timed to 16-17-17-34-1 @1.39VSamsung 970 Pro 512GB + 5 other various HDD and SSDsCorsair H115i ProCorsair AX1200i PSUCorsair 750D Case
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 14, 2019

title: Great processor for the money.
content: I ordered this processor to build a photo editing PC for work, but ended up buying a better GPU and turning it into a gaming PC and taking it home when the job didn‚Äôt work out. No regrets! This processor is great for varying work loads, and it‚Äôs a huge upgrade from the quad core i5 system that I was using prior to this.Overall very happy with this processor. May be ordering a Ryzen 9 3950x to upgrade my gaming PC, then building another work PC and installing this CPU in it, just for future proofing. But I guess time will tell.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 11, 2019

title: Likely the Bang for the Buck in CPUs!
content: I build a lot of computers, and purchase this CPU for a secondary computer in my workshop....that streams music while I work, and handles 3  monitors/screens of security cameras.  I installed in on a Asus Strix B450 motherboard, 16gb/3400 Gskill RAM, and a 240mm corsair AIO cooler.  Fired right up first time, and installed Win10.... After everything was installed, I ran Ryzen Master OC software.....and it is now running stable AT 4.275GHz/1.425 volts..... at 34C!!!!  WOW!!!  I ran a number of test with Ryzen Master, and found that for my chip.....that is the top end,  But WOW!  That is better performance/overclocking then I can achieve with a Ryzen 2700X!!!  ABSOLUTELY THE BEST BANG FOR THE BUCK IN CPUs!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2019

title: Super Fast But gets hot
content:
Your browser does not support HTML5 video.


  ¬†I give this 5 stars for it runs like a champ, had to ramp up the fans to keep it from shutting down the PC. I plan to get an All in One water cooler soon. It arrived late with all the other parts I got with it, but that was due to UPS messing up my telephone numbers. However, the box was well protected and well sealed, and I cannot say enough about how stable this little processor is.Mine came stock at 3.85ghz and boosts up to 4.1ghz. I told windows to only use 70% of its power to ensure it does not overheat. I also believe due to living in a tropical island and its the summer, I have to only run low-end games but this baby can run games at 140fps and higher with the right GPU. Paired with the RX 5700XT I am impressed, but it needs cooling at high loads. I can play Black Desert Online Remastered with no issue, but Shadow of the Tomb Raider on Ultra gets super hot really fast. So pick your poison wisely if you live in a hot country like me. Also got tonnes of fans and I have great airflow, but until I get proper cooling I will play games that don't demand too much pressure.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 26, 2019

title: De las mejores compras para procesador Gaming o trabajo por debajo de los 130 usd.
content: Muy buen procesador, un rendimiento muy bueno en comparaci√≥n con los procesadores que rondan su precio. En especial para Gaming si posees una tarjeta gr√°fica de buen rendimiento.Recomiendo cambiar el disipador pues en de serie suele dejar calentar un poco tocando los 80¬∞ en mi caso en una habitaci√≥n con temp de 29¬∞. Por tal motivo recomendar√≠a cualquier disipador por aire dedicado que dan unas buenas temperatura. Actualmente estoy con en hyper 212 Evo y no sube m√°s de 64¬∞ en carga.Por √∫ltimo si est√° en tu presupuesto recomiendo ir por el 2700x que viene en picada con un futuro bastante largo por su n√∫mero de n√∫cleos adicionales. O ir directamente por el 3600 por su rendimiento para juegos.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2020

title: Simple to install, great performance for gaming and for work!
content: When I was ready to install this into my first PC build, I was super nervous that I would break a pin or something. I could not have been more surprised with the ease of installation with this CPU. I lined the gold triangle with where it coordinated on my B450 Tomahawk motherboard, placed it in, and moved it very lightly to insure that it was fully in place. The locking mechanism for AM4 is super simple. Way easier than Intel. You just pulled down the retention rod and lock it in.This is offered the best price per performance than anything in the Ryzen line up. I love this CPU and love that AMD has offered a product that competes with Intel. AMD's new Ryzen cards will only get better from here as the new processes for producing these CPUs become more efficient and powerful. I highly would recommend choosing an AMD CPU or Intel in today's market. They just make more sense for the average consumer and for most creators, especially when you have limits on how much you can spend on a PC build or upgrade. In today's market, and probably for the coming year (2019), it just doesn't make any sense for someone to go buy an Intel CPU given the price per performance.
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 6, 2019

title: It's just as good as they say.
content: I have been using an Core i5 computer for about 4 years, and it was very fast for its time and still pretty fast, but I've been reading about how fast the Ryzen CPUs are, so I finally gave in to the temptation and built a new computer with the Ryzen 5 2600.  Well, it's just as fast as advertised, and it runs cool and quiet with the Wraith Stealth cooler. My only hiccup was that when I tried attaching the CPU cooler, it has four screws, so you have to remove the clamps that came on the motherboard.  When I did that, the metal back plate fell off, so I had to partially disassemble the computer to reach the back plate and hold it in place while I screwed the CPU cooler to it.  In hindsight, it would be better to attach the CPU and cooler to the motherboard before installing the motherboard into the computer case.  Once I got past that hiccup, everything went smoothly, and the Ryzen 5 really is faster than a Core i5, and much less expensive.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 18, 2019

title: Excellent value and performance
content: I bought this for my first build. I didn't know anything about computers at the time, but I was simply baffled at how expensive Intel's processors were compared to AMD's. There was probably a good reason for that, but me not wanting to pay an arm and a leg for a 6 core, I chose the 2600.At 6 cores and 12 threads, while also being unlocked and coming with a good cooler for standard use, the Ryzen 5 2600 is a great bargain and performer. So far it has performed well in games and hasn't run too hot (with the stock cooler!). I cannot speak for other workloads besides gaming and general tasks, but it does those two remarkably well, often in tandem. All without breaking the bank. And this was when it was around the 160-170 dollar range, and has fallen even farther since then.And after hearing about the great success of Zen2, I will absolutely be getting another Ryzen chip for my next build. Very impressive.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: Affordable, fast, and powerful!
content: The AMD 2600, 6c/12t processor, bought for 150$ during the holidays is the mind of a budget computer you want!Pros:Overclocking the processor over 4ghz was easy and a must for each grain of performance,The cpu fan that comes with the processor was quiet and kept the cool --especially while underload,Shipping was fast and worry free,I lost the sticker,Cpu supports fast ddr4 memory, I only 3000mhz and it worked fine,Instruction manuel.Cons:Finding a cheap motherboard for the processor with the am4 socket AND with support for 2nd gen ryzen was and will be a struggle,I lost the sticker,Not enough people are buying this cpu.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Solid processor for modest gaming rig
content: Purchased this processor for my girlfriends first gaming rig. We didn't need anything too demanding, but rather an all around workhorse. This baby, paired with a RX580, does most of what we could ask for in terms of playing some older AAA games at decent settings(if not ultra). This processor has served well for its purpose. It maintains low temps and is easy to install with the exception of the fan. The fan that it comes with requires a bit of tinkering and more pressure than you would expect to seat it properly. It literally was the bottleneck with regards to the full computer build. Alas when installed it does as advertised. If the newer Zen products didn't exist now I'd purchase it again.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2019

title: I am not a gamer. But works great and fast.
content: This was my first build ever. I will tell you they do not give you much directions. So make sure you watch enough YouTube videos to help you with that. But I did have a computer background so I did know enough to get me through. This is a great little processor. It is fast without even over clocking. I am not a gamer and I find it transcodes my videos just fine so far. I have not run into a hicup yet with it. Runs really cool with just the stock cooler and three case fans. I leave mine on 24/7 but it does go into sleep mode at night. I have yet to try video editing but streaming works great. No lag time what so ever. Great processor for the money.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2019

title: It going to be Ryzen for me from now on it looks like.
content: It will be hard to find the words and write how happy I am with my new Ryzen. Just unbeatable performance for an unbeatable price. If you don't have a Ryzen powered system, then you need to build one now. This processor is a workhorse.I used to buy Intel and only use Intel, but this Ryzen purchase changed that for me forever.A word of advice to new builders using Ryzen:Make sure you install windows and COMPLETELY update your system before installing new programs like Chrome and others. If you just install Windows and then start installing programs before making sure you have all of the latest updates first, you will end up with a very buggy experience that you can't fix and will end up resetting your computer.First- install Windows.Second- Check for updates and make sure they install.Third- Check againFourth- Check againFifth-Check againSixth- when there are no more updates available, then go ahead and start putting on what programs you want.Following this will save you a lot of headaches.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 18, 2020

title: From a cinebench of 332/52 to 1301/111 in 300 easy dollars
content: just upgraded my trusty Zeon e5450@3.1GHz/1333MHz to this.... lol wut.First real upgrade in 5 years...  switched my MB/CPU/RAM (kept old gfx card (hd7850)) from my trusty old zeon E5450 OC'd to 3.1GHz and 1333MHz DDR3 -also locked multiplier :(  ... to the R2 2600 (DDR4 3200MHz) with NO lock. night and day. Great performance for the cost. Easy to OC.Cinibench scores can't even tell it all... across the board, all peripherals operate insanely faster.  The CPU is no longer the bottleneck for anything I do.

title: Great if the price is right.
content: Paired with a tower cooler and a msi b450 gaming pro plus with gaming mode enabled hwmonitor is reporting peak clock speeds of 5.4ghz to 5.6ghz across all 6 cores and a peak temp of 73c while running folding@home 24\7 and media streaming at the same time, I do keep my home at 60f. Only purchase this if it's under $120, you can find better bang for your buck if it costs more than that. I got mine for $119.99
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 20, 2019

title: My best decision of 2018
content: This CPU packs a heavy six-core punch at such low price. I was saving up since some time for my PC upgrade (from A8-7600). Resisted my urge when AMD launched Ryzen 1st Gen assuming that 2nd Gen would pack a lot of improvement looking at AMD's zeal.And man, they didn't disappoint. With better single thread performance and improved memory compatibility with jawdropping price I finally took the decision.Pros:1. At around $150-160, the six-core, twelve-thread monster is unbeatable.2. Breezes through multi-threaded workloads. My CPU util while gaming, which kept lurking beyond 95% previously, is now stays below 35%.3. Stock cooler (Wraith Stealth), though the smallest one in Ryzen family, does a decent job at stock speeds. 65 deg C was the max temperature I've seen under heavy workload.4. AM4 socket has long life as promised by AMD. I can easily switch to a 7nm Ryzen offering significant performance gain, in future. This would save me need of buying a new motherboard.Cons:None that I could think of.
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 8, 2018

title: Really good 6-Core CPU!
content: For the price, you can't go wrong with this 6-core CPU. I upgraded from a quad-core Ryzen CPU and the speed difference was actually pretty noticable. The extra two cores made a pretty big difference, IMHO. It runs all the stuff I have thrown at it so far without a hitch. I mainly watch videos (streaming, blu-rays, and DVDs), browse the internet, and listen to music on my PC, so I can't say how well it works for gaming. However, I'm sure it'll do an overall good job, since the specs of this CPU are good. Definitely worth every penny spent! Highly recommended.
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 1, 2020

title: Best bang for buck CPU in 2019
content: Great processor for an amazing value especially in 2019. 6 cores and 12 threads makes it a great gaming processor as well as a decent workstation processor. Runs games really well and doesn't get too hot even with the stock cooler. Averages about 35C idle and about 45-50C under load. If you don't like those temps, get an aftermarket cooler. Overall is an amazing cpu for the price. I paid $109.99 when I bought it.I gave it 4 stars in gaming because of one reason. As far as performance is concerned, its not the best chip. Intel Core i5 8700K or Ryzen 5 3600 would be better for gaming because they perform better than the 2600 and still match the 2600 with 6 cores and 12 threads. With performance, you could buy better. With price, there's no better deal.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2018

title: Worth the upgrade
content: I have been rocking the older fx8300 chip for the past 10 years and was still getting good performance, but was feeling the pinch in certain games and even when doing video encoding. I finally broke down and got a new setup using the R5 2600 and was blown away by how much I was missing out on. FPS in games jumped by 40-50, and my videos which took around 20mins to encode now only take 9mins.  I was going to wait for the new 3000 series but I know that the drivers for this are mature enough to be stable.The only thing I can say that you might want to consider is an aftermarket cooling solution. Yes, this comes with a cooler, but is extremely under performing. I also added a evo212 and drop idle temps from 30-32c to 22-25c and turbo also can "see" this thermal headroom and jumps accordingly.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: Great AMD brand - horrible Amazon packaging
content: Not bashing AMD here as I've got two other AMD Ryzen builds and they are great. This CPU was going to be my son's upgrade from a Ryzen 3 1200 on a ASUS micto-atx mobo. BIOS are flashed to the most recent 5220 to ensure mobo life up to 3rd gen Ryzen.I'm blaming more Amazon shipping. The Amazon shipping box the CPU came in had loads of room - with no padding whatsoever so the CPU box was knocked around along with other sensitive electronics. Needless to say, I'm sure this is the reason the CPU was DOA while shipping. I also had a dual-kit of RAM shipped on the same package - and one stick is defective. I don't think it's a coincidence. Both are awaiting replacement - the RAM kit has already been acknowledge and a replacement is on the way. Still waiting to hear back on the like-for-like replacement from Amazon in regards to the CPU. Luckily Amazon's return process is smooth so I just dropped off the defective parts at Kohl's.I'll update the review once I get shipping confirmation on the new and verified it's working.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Quiet, cool, and powerful.
content: I'm extremely impressed with this processor and cooler.  My idle temps are 30 celius and load averages 58 and never goes above 60 celsius.  I hopped into a fresh Minecraft world and the game rendered instantly.  All my games I can run on max settings.  Very satisfied.However, the cooler was almost impossible to install.  Read reviews of the wraith stealth cooler you'll see it's very hard to screw down.  I was afraid of breaking my processor and motherboard because of how hard I had to press just to screw a corner in.  And many times I screwed it in it tilted the rest of the cooler up so high it could not reach the sockets.  Took my at least an hour to screw it in.  Here is some advice just screw one corner in very very lightly then the opposite one the same and continue to lightly screw it in until you know it is secure then finish screwing it in.Overall I'm very satisfied regardless of the installation process.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 24, 2019

title: Excellent
content: I was quite blown away with how well this processor performs. I wasn't expecting to double my framerates in some games, so that was a pleasant surprise. I was still using a Phenom II until recently, so it's not a huge surprise in of itself that a very new processor would it eat it alive, but for the price, this seems to be the best CPU on the market right now if value is important to you.

title: Everything it is supposed to be
content: This proc is everything and more. Games, productivity video editing, sound editing, app development. For the average user(not a AAA gamer, programmer or other specialized group) this proc and I am sure the next gen of it are over kill. But for the rest of us it is the money spot at sub 120.00 6 cores 12 threads it does everything and I do mean everything. We can talk clock speed and IPC all day. But lets be honest in productivity , app development, editing and even gaming) you are not going to see or feel any difference when compared to an Intel part. However you can see and feel the difference in the cost savings.  I am comparing this experience to my daily driver at my 9-5 which is a 10core 20thread Intel proc.

title: A very good cpu
content: It works, the pins are durable to the point that it's insane. The performance is amazing for the low price, and this cpu alone made me love AMD. The only issue I had was once the cpu actually malfunctioned and made the pc crash numerous times, and it actually messed up the motherboard BIOS. When I got a new cpu of the same kind, I never had the problem again, and I got a full refund.

title: Great for gaming!
content: I brought this for my first gaming rig. The installation was pretty easy with the instructions included giving all the information needed.I am experienced in putting together a PC and the CPU fan has allways been a headache, not with this Wraith fan, it's very easy to install and the space it takes makes it compact enough for me to use it in a Micro ATX configuration without colliding with the RAM or anything.The performance is amazing considering that this is a second gen Ryzen. I've paired with a RTX 2070 super and found that all the games run smoothly on 1080.

title: Processor is fantastic. Included cooler, not so much (EDIT)
content: Absolutely fantastic product in terms of processing power at an affordable price, especially for building your own PC. Above and beyond expectations. However, the stock "Wraith Stealth" cooler that was included came defective. After installing the processor, applying the cooler was easy but something clearly did not work in terms of the spring assisted screws (on a compatible motherboard). After running the new machine the idling temperature was way too hot, at around 74 degrees.Disappointed that I had to buy a new cooler on my own a few moments ago instead of sending and waiting for a full return (and then waiting for a whole new unit) as the cooler is at fault, not the processor.Otherwise, the actual, physical processor is awesome and big kudos to AMD for making yet another spectacular product.EDIT- After purchasing the new separate Wraith Spire cooler, the CPU is running great at cool temperatures. Must have been a fluke cooler. Don't let that stop you from buying the processor! Updated to 4 stars.

title: BEASTMODE ENGAGED!
content: The little engine that could. I always read these forums or sites stating you always need the latest and greatest to do anything online. I bought 2 of these and mine oc‚Äôd @3.95 and my wife‚Äôs @3.83. It‚Äôs bad to bone, video game crunching, work/tasks destroyer of worlds. And for $119.99 when I bought them, I could not be happier. I game heavy and work from home, and this CPU does it all and asked for nothing in return.
