title: Consistent Speed Performance
content: This is one super CPU.  The speed is consistent.  Its reliability is constant.  I have had it installed for a month now with no hiccups or failures.  Runs beautifully.One item of note, the CPU requires a "Discreet Graphics Card"  At first that threw me for loop, and to make it worse I could not find any information of what the heck is a discreet graphics card.  Finally I found that it only means an external graphics card.  I found that without an external graphics card plugged in, the CPU negates the Motherboard built-in graphics capability.  As far as which graphics card it accepts, I found no information.  I did have an Nvidia GeForce GTX 560 which is about 10 years old, The CPU recognized it and has been working fine since.
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 10, 2019

title: Awesome
content: My last desktop was a quad core unlocked Phenom (that's correct, not the Phenom II) After that I got a laptop with a quad core A10 APU.  This CPU blows both away by a huge margin.  I can't compare this with an Intel chip as the last one I owned was some Pentium that blew after 13 months.  It came in an eMachine (NEVER OBSOLETE!!) so I'm lucky to still have all of my fingers.Installation was (mostly) a breeze, Lift socket lever, drop in CPU minding the marked corner, push lever back down.  The "mostly" part is that my motherboard came with brackets to hold down the CPU cooler.  They are useless for this unit as the heat sink and fan screw in to the back plate directly.  I had to unscrew the brackets and then when screwing the new cooler on I had to juggle the back plate, cooler, and motherboard while turning the screws.  Not too hard but, still a pain in the butt.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: Super impressed
content: I went back & forth for weeks leading up to my purchase whether or not I'd get the 2600 or the 2600X CPU and settled on going with the 2600 and saving $50 (US).  I'm super glad I did.  I haven't taken any time to overclock the chip yet but at stock I've already tested streaming games using the CPU to do the encoding and now that I've figure out how to best setup everything for this, the CPU has been able to handle it without a single issue.  Additionally, the price vs performance of this CPU is amazing.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: This is THE best processor at this price point.
content: Hands down best CPU value out there. This thing is seriously a beast at the price point, for mixed use cases like 1080p gaming, music production, photo editing, and intermediate video editing it is absolutely perfect, the stock cooler is nice and this thing stays REALLY cool, I haven't seen it go over 65¬∞c yet using stock cooler in my Meshify C. Overall very impressed and very proud to see AMD pushing out great products like these. Installation of AM4 chips is a breeze and the stock cooler was also very simple to mount.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 26, 2019

title: The Absolute Best Processor for Your Money
content: This thing comes pre-overclocked. If you just drop it into the socket and turn off cool and quiet mode it will run at 3.8 GHz (0.4 GHz more than it says on the box) even if the motherboard isn't capable of OC. The ease at which this thing overclocks is absolutely crazy. There's also a little known app for the type of processor called the Ryzen Master App that will manage the processor, the voltage and the RAM overclocking. With a tweak and a restart it makes changing overclock settings really easy. The only thing you need is a motherboard capable of  overclocking a processor (for just tweaking the settings).
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 4, 2018

title: Best price/performance gaming CPU
content: This replaced my AMD Athlon II X3 in my gaming machine that had soldiered on for over 7 years. This is far and above the best price/performance CPU on the market. Paired with a modest GTX 1060 3gig graphics card and 16G DDR4 3200 RAM, on an ASRock B450M PRO4 motherboard it runs everything like a champ at 1080p high or ultra without breaking a sweat. I've gone from being limited by my CPU to being limited by my GPU.Installation was easy. The CPU comes with thermal paste already applied, but I applied my own.It can be overclocked, but the overclocking software is bewildering, and I haven't had a need to overclock.The only downside is the stock cooler fan is louder than I prefer, louder than my GPU fans. Gaming with headphones on it's not notable, but I like my PCs to be nearly silent. It's possible this can be fixed by tweaking the fan controls.Pros:* Best price/performance* Easy installation* Can be overclocked* Handles 1080p gaming no problemCons:* Fan is noisier than I'd like* Bewildering overclocking software
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2018

title: All the CPU you will ever need.
content: I bought this CPU here on Amazon for $114.99 a month ago for a build I put together for my wife.  I put the Wraith Prism cooler from my build that I got when I bought my Ryzen 3700X on her 2600 and brought the temps down 6 degrees C from the original Spire cooler that came with the 2600.  All in all, the Ryzen 5-2600 CPU is a workhorse and is all anyone would need for workstation and gaming.  It is fast and steady.  I installed 16GB of Corsair RGB 3200mhz RAM on an MSI B450 Tomahawk Max mobo and using a GTX750 Nvidia 2 GB graphics card from a previous off the shelf rig, this rig does very well.  I will eventually upgrade the graphics card as it is a bottleneck but for what my wife needs, it works fine.  I highly recommend the Ryzen 5 2600 as it is a great value chip and will serve well.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 25, 2018

title: Great Except for one thing.....
content: The CPU is everything I expected.  However the only issue is the pre-applied paste and cooler.  The packaging allows dust to get in and there was dust on my thermal paste that I could not remove.  It was new and seal but dust made its way in.  AMD you need to do better at packaging these.  I knocked it by 1 star for this reason.  So far the processor is great.
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 14, 2019

title: Great Budget gaming CPU
content: I have nothing bad to say about this CPU due to the fact that it works great and pairs nice with my GPU! I built my gaming PC last week and wanted to wait before posting to give me time to test everything out. The parts include:MOBO: Tomahawk B450 MaxCPU: AMD Ryzen 5 2600GPU: MSI Geforce RTX 2060RAM: PAtriot Viper 4 Blackout series DDR4 16GB(2x8) 3000mhzSSD: Kingston 480GB A400HDD: Still waitingI am able to maintain above 90 FPS, on ultimate settings, on Rainbow 6 Siege, Apex Legends, WOW, etc... The CPU pairs well with the GPU and causes no bottle necking issues and the wraith spiral cooler that comes with it, even though standard, performs great and my temps maintain around 41c when idle and below 75c when gaming. If you're looking for a budget friendly CPU that performs great, I would suggest this one. Remember, always check your CPU or GPU when thinking about purchasing them to make sure there is no bottle necks and to see how your FPS might look. I cannot say enough great things about this CPU and, again, if your on a budget, I would suggest this!

title: Great little workhorse - even for today
content: I am running this with two M.2 drives, 16GB of G-Skill RAM and a GTX 1060 (6GB) on an MSI 470x motherboard. It runs much faster and cooler than I had first imagined, even though it is running close to it's top clock speed. It is handling the Excel spreadsheets that I need to run and well as a web app that run pretty much 24-7.

title: pretty good cpu
content: After waiting for my cpu to be shipped and the order being cancelled by some mysterious figure I reordered and Today I received the cpu now right off the bat I started unpacking the ryzen 5 box and wanted to get rid of my ryzen 3 1200 ASAP little did I know the cpu fan had no pre installed thermal paste and I had no thermal paste for back up I noticed this after I took out my ryzen 3 and now I sit here computerless because the thermal that would normally be there was no where to be found when I get to use the computer I‚Äôll edit the review but as for now I can‚Äôt do anything about itEDIT: After getting the paste turns out this cpu is a beast never before have I seen such power in my computer given the only problem was not receiving pre installed thermal paste dis was a good purchase yes

title: WHY IS MY THIS PROCESSOR SO SLOW COULD IT BE THE POPUP WINDOW I GET?
content: i LIKE THAT THE PROCESSOR IS SUPPOSED TO BE FASTER THAN MY RYZEN 3 I HAD BEFORE I UPGRADED TO THIS ONE. BUT I HAVE ISSUES: I have a Sunflower MB on my HP Pavilion 520- desktop.  MB is 8433 11. According to the MB manufacturer this processor AMD Ryzen 5 2600 Processor with Wraith Stealth Cooler would work with it. . The installation was easy but I COULD NOT install the Wraith Stealth Cooler. It would not fit or work. So I had to install the original fan that came with the Ryzen 3 so now I can't overclock it. I also installed an graphic card from an old PC for now, the AMD Radeon HD 6450.. I don't use my PC for gaming, only for multitasking and Creative Cloud and social media.  I also have upgraded the memory to Mushkin Enhanced Redline 16GB (2 x 8GB) 288-Pin DDR4 SDRAM DDR4 3200...a few months ago, running at 2133MHz instead of the 2666mhz.  HERE IS MY MAIN PROBLEM:  when my pc boots up, it boots up very slow and once it gets to the desktop, I can't do anything until I close the window that pops up everytime which is C:\ WINDOWS \ system32 \ windowspowershell \ v1.0 \powershell.exe. I have to click it a few times by the time it closes it. HOW DO I PREVENT THIS COMING POPPING UP EVERYTIME I REBOOT MY PC AND WHAT DO I DO ABOUT THE WRAITH STEALTH COOLER THAT CAME WITH IT? HOW DO I GET THE CORRECT ONE AND MY POWER SUPPY is 180watts so will I also need to upgrade that too? What fan cooler that is silent do I need before overclocking my processor? WHY IS MY NEW UPGRADE SO SLOW? THANK!

title: Ryzen Up
content: I am new to AMD but I am not disappointed. This cpu is a work horse for such a low power draw. Highly recommended If you are building a pc on a budget. Comes with a cpu fan, pre-applied thermal paste, and free games. Performs just a little lesser than it's intel counterpart for this generation but it's literally 80 dollars cheaper so it's a no brainer here.Combined with the AM4 mobo you got a solid build. Easy to update and configure, no problems with post using generic RAM etc. In combo with RX 500 line of AMD GPUs it should play new games on high settings if that is your deal.10/10 would compute again
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Really excellent value, fast CPU.
content: The Ryzen CPUs are hands-down the best value you can get for the money.  Sure, the Intel CPUs are faster, but you pay through the nose for that speed.  The Ryzens are plenty fast enough... even fairly close to the Intels, but the real kicker is that the price differential is so huge now that the difference can be used to significant buf the rest of the machine... enough to buy another 8G or 16G of ram and/or a better GPU, or that SSD you always wanted.  If you don't have an infinite budget to spend on your machine, you can get a much better Ryzen-based machine for the same money, no question about it.  5-stars.-Matt
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 3, 2019

title: Great balanced CPU for one who wants power but is frugal
content: This is a great budget Ryzen 5 chip and I easily overclocked to 4ghz. I do use an aftermarket dual fan heatsink though. At 4ghz it's showing as 1.4 vcore which is fine for this chip. CPU on full load using all cores never gets above 70c which is under the AMD max value. Could cool it more with a lower vcore, but at 1.35 it was wonky. No complaints and many have said 1.4 is the absolute max and should be fine with proper cooling which to me makes sense. Runs 24/7 smoothly with zero problems. Running multiple benchmarks show it was a tiny bit better than the 2600x. Not bad!
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 21, 2019

title: My First choice if you're upgrading from an FX8350
content: Have to say i've been running the FX series processors from amd since 2013. I have bought this for 165 usd.Worth the upgrade from the FX8350 lineup. No issues with lagging or frame skips.The old processors was bottlenecking the RX 480 with each graphics card update and occasional blue screens. And most of the my hardware was losing its quality of life.And it was the right time to upgrade when Ram prices got back to normal. Thank God the crypto Market fade was dying off.Most importance note it's worth the upgrade. If you stream or record games in VR.

title: A solid processor for gaming on a budget
content: I have this paired with an EVGA GTX 1080 for gaming on dual 1440p monitors (75 Hz) and it has been a champ. It has also served me quite well for compiling on Linux. A word of caution for anyone that has bought memory using SK Hynix ICs, you probably won't ever get your memory up to 3200 MHz due to it not playing nice with Ryzen's memory controller. I have a G.Skill Trident CL16 kit I cannot push past 2933 MHz, but the proc itself with my Cryorig H7 I can hit 4.1 GHz manual OC (all core). If you don't plan on doing any overclocking, I would recommend going for the 2600X due to the higher binned chip hitting better "turbo" overclocking that B450/X470 boards will do automatically.

title: Faulty CPU

Even after preforming a bios update the CPU still wouldn't boot my PC. On a side note the CPU came in package without any padding (so I could imagine how many hits it took before it got to me) and it has visible dust on the box itself so I could only assume its been on a shelf longer then it needed to be. I would of liked to exchange the CPU for another one but my only option was to return it. This isn't the first time I had problems with computers parts I've purchased off of amazon so Im now only getting my parts off of NewEgg. I've never felt so disappointed when buying a product online before.

title: AMD promotional games can be non-redeemable
content: I honestly built my new gaming system in part due to the promotional elements of both the video card I purchased and this processor. My frustration lies not in the processors performance, but in AMDs unwillingness to help me redeem my games that came as promotional items. I couldn't afford to do a complete build that could power on in one shot (I had the video card, processor and M2 SATA drive), but was waiting to save up the funds for the RAM, Motherboard, and PSU. So I contacted them directly as directed by their FAQ, which stated they could help me with an alternative means of redemption for the coupon codes (you are sent a coupon code, then you need to register with  AMDRewards, then install hardware verification software, then they send you the actual codes) if you couldn't install the software. They declined to help me after a several week back and fourth.Anyways, since that was a partial reason for purchase, and it was flat out denied me since I couldn't afford to build a complete system at the time, I'm giving the review 1 star.

title: Buy a fan/heatsink, keep the CPU!

title: For the most part, its the Best Band-For-Buck out currently
content: I read online forums where users said the upgrade from the Ryzen 3 1300X to this processor wouldnt really be worth the upgrade and I'd had to strongly disagree. Yes, the 1300X is an incredible value for the price and has more than enough power for most every tasks, but I saw a dramatic difference in my Video editing speeds and rendering speed after Upgrading to this 2600 CPU. The Wraith cooling fan is the same that comes with the 1300X but thus far I haven't had any issues with overheating so I don't know that its much of an issue. Having had some experience building a gaming rig or two(I'm an IT guy by trade) with the upgraded 1700, Id probably say the this CPU is the perfect bang-for-buck in the Ryzen series thus far. To get a processor this fast for around 180 bucks(at the time if purchase) is pretty insane. I'd highly recommend the Ryzen 5 2600.

title: High pitched noise
content: This review is mainly important for younger people. I'm in my 20's and I can hear a high pitched frequency coming from the CPU cooler fan. I keep my computer running 24/7 in my bedroom and I can hear it at night while trying to sleep, even over my noise cancelling headphones. If you keep your computer in any other room then this should not be an issue for you. I tried to have other people much older than myself and closer to my age listen in on it and none of the older people could hear it. I'm going to order a different CPU cooler, other than the noise issue everything else about this product is perfectly fine.I also made sure to identify that the fan is indeed making the noise. I took the side panel off my case and made sure it was not coming from anywhere else.

title: Best value on the market
content: Great CPU for everyday use, can handle everything I throw at it including some demanding games such as the newer Total War games along with Paradox games. While Intel CPU's may have better single thread performance and will run games better on a side by side comparison, this does not account for the fact that most people multitask while playing games or doing work projects, giving the AMD CPU a great advantage in terms of that. If you want a CPU that is both cheap and very effective at running multiple demanding programs such as for example; games+web browser+music: This CPU is for you. title: A great chip for the cost

title: Wraith cooler stripped out backplate screws
content: For the time being I'm giving this two stars simply because the CPU cooler stripped out the backplate screw holes. The screws in the Wraith cooler are woefully short and the pressure springs are so strong that once the screws are in the backplate threads they start ripping threads (no pun intended) out of the backplate. I just had to order a new cooler to replace the included cooler.If I can ever get this working then I'll update the review but it's been a nightmare so far.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 10, 2019

title: Very good processor
content: The item arrived in a very short time (remarkable, given that it was an international shipment) in perfect conditions. Though I can't say I've put it in some serious stress, for what I've seen so far it works pretty fast without overheating (which could sound obvious in November, but the room where I keep the pc is quite exposed to sunlight and thus a little hot even in winter).The box doesn't include a disk with the control panel, but it can easily be downloaded from AMD's site.Mounting the cooler isn't hard at all, but it requires a little bit of attention in the screw tightening process 'cause it could tilt a bit and thus not adhere properly. It could also be a problem of the motherboard, however, or a problem that all coolers share. I'm no expert on the matter.Anyway, great product and low price, expecially if bought discounted like I did.

title: With the Asus X370-F Motherboard upgrade your Bios before installing this CPU.
content: So, i got this CPU for the Asus X370-F MB, the MB didn‚Äô post, it was just marking the Ram yellow light, i switched the memories, used like 4 different dims and nothing happened, i was almost sure that the problem was the motherboard then my last resort was testing the board with another CPU, i borrowed a Ryzen 7 1st gen from a friend and after mounting it, boom! it worked. So in order to use this CPU with that MB you have to update the Bios first.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 28, 2018

title: Don't waste your money on the X
content: Even if you are fairly new to overclocking or don't plan to at all, the R5 2600 is still by far the best value. You can get away with the stock cooler with a slight overclock or with the $50+ you save from not buying the 2600X, you can get an entry level 120mm AIO liquid cooler or a really beefy air cooler. Then OC to your hearts content. Look at it this way,. The 2600X is about 5% faster out of the box for 25% more money and Intel just doesn't compete in the $150 price range and there is no guarantee that your current Intel chip will work on the next generation of motherboards. AMD has promised that Ryzen chips will work across 4 generations motherboards. So future proof and plenty powerful for both AAA gaming and production. Ryzen generally speaking may loose a few hundred Mhz to Intel hear and there but don't let that scare you off. Its only a small percentage that most people would never notice unless they had an fps counter running on screen while gaming. You're money is much better served to buy this chip and then a better graphics card then an Intel chip for $200 more and a lesser GPU. AMD has really shaken up the market in a good way and left Intel scrambling. Nothing against Intel.. I also own an i5 6600K and its been a good gaming chip. But in price to performance AMD wins bigtime.
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2018

title: Good CPU but the stock fan...
content: I recently bought this CPU and it works fine, but when I purchased a 144 Hertz monitor the FPS went down. I recently downloaded Ryzen Master and was checking my CPU temp. Also was thinking about overclocking but, with the stock fan the temp goes up to 85 Celsius when I'm playing MW. That's with 3.4 GHz, so I would recommend buying a different fan that will not go above 80 Celsius. I would also recommend overclocking if you are a gamer and trying to have good performance in which I would buy another fan. I would also recommend downloading Ryzen Master to check the temp and would also allow you to stress test your CPU. I would give it 5 stars, but I feel like a lot of people wouldn't know how to overclock and would just keep it at 3.4 GHz if they know nothing about computers.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 26, 2018

title: I used a ryzen 5 2600 for my first ever PC build
content: I am new to PC building, but one weekend I looked up a tutorial on how to build a PC and it seemed rather easy to me, so I took the challenge. With being on a budget I was able to build something that could handle gaming at 1080p 60fps and school work (mainly for gaming). I ended up going with the ryzen 5 instead of the ryzen 3 just so I wouldn't have to upgrade anytime soon incase I wanted to do stuff that required more of my CPU. The installation required some pressure in order for the screws to catch the thread of the backplate, but after that it was a straight forward install. I ended up swapping out the stock fan for an aftermarket one, was it necessary, probably not. The kind of task I do with it is, game and stream mostly and it still runs smoothly, no hiccups. As I'm still gettin my feet wet with PC building I can say I am happy with my decision and bang for my buck. I would recommend this to others who are on a budget and want good performance
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 17, 2018

title: Love it!
content: Got this CPU to replace an AMD X6-1055.  Had 16GB on old motherboard.  Now using a B450 motherboard with 16GB and the Ryzen 5-2600.  Very happy with the speed, AND the fact that the CPU draws only 65Watts.  Not into gaming or anything like that, but use the computer for everyday use.  I also tend to keep a motherboard/CPU combination for some time.  Running Linux Mint 19.3 Mate on all my computers here.  Very stable, and very quick on updates!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 3, 2020

title: Great CPU for the price!

I paired it with an Asus ROG Strix B450-F Gaming MB, 16 GB of G.Skill TridentZ RGB 3200 Ram and my already owned EVGA GTX 1060 3 GB video card. It has proven to be be everything I have read about it and more. I am running it at 4GHz OC'd with an Arctic 33 esports edition cooler which keeps it idling at around 29-30 C and at around 54C while gaming. Overall I am extremely satisfied with this CPU.

title: My next personal build will be with Ryzen
content: My current build is an 8700k and a 2080 Ti, no doubt a performance power house, but severely lacking in the price to performance category. lol Since I have built my own rig many of my friends have reached out to me for builds and parts lists. This CPU has been in every rig/list I have thrown together in the past 6 months, and with the release of 3rd gen, the price drops on 2nd make this a no brainer for it's power. It can easily reach 4.2 ghz on water making an absolute beast for gaming. The last rig I built for my friend was a Ryzen 2600 and an RX 580 8GB, that thing can run Ark on high settings at 60+ FPS 1440p! Throw a 2600, some dual channel memory @3+ ghz, an SSD, and a midrange GPU and you have yourself a badass machine for $700-$800.
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 24, 2018

title: Good Gaming CPU
content: bought this back in 2018 to replace a i5 2500k rig. Not a big boost in IPC, but multicore is better. Anything that requires the 6 cores is no problem for this processor. it took about 45 minutes to unzip a 20GB file with my 2500k. It took this processor about 3 minutes. Cool. The FPS stayed about the same in games, but I certainly noticed less stutter. Currently using this with a 1080p 144hz display with a GTX 1070, and its just perfect. I don't play the modern stuff, so its easy to reach the 144hz needed for the display. I know that the 3600 or other high core count cpus exist, but if you want something decent for the price, get this.

title: Awesome CPU
content: The stock clock speed and single thread rating is slightly higher than the Ryzen 7. I was going to try the Ryzen 7 2700, but the TDP is the same as the Ryzen 5 2600. The Ryzen 5 2600X was turned down because the TDP is almost double the 2600 for only a .3 Ghz increase. (more TDP=more CPU heat=overkill cooling needed). Plus, two more cores on the Ryzen 7 didn't seem a big deal for an extra $100. I do suggest finding a new heat-sink, CPU fan, and thermal compound. Stock provided is not worthy. I love this CPU. Excited to see what AMD has done with the next gen CPU coming later this year.

title: One of the best budget processors available
content: Ended up purchasing this processor instead of the Ryzen 5 3600 as its price dropped down to approx $120, and also because the available motherboards (B450/X470) support it out of the box. I didn't want to risk getting a board with a bios that doesn't support Zen 2 or bricking a board in my attempt to upgrade its single bios chip.I am a bit disappointed and impressed at the performance. I'm disappointed at the single-thread performance because most of my applications are not multi-thread optimised. I am however impressed when my apps are taking advantage of the multiple cores and threads; it doesn't appear to let up in completing tasks. I am actively thinking of ways to make use of the extra cores. The idle power consumption is very similar to my Core I3-6100 but it does climb to double under load.I must thank AMD for allowing me to reuse my old CPU cooler (Xigmatek Dark Knight HDT-S1283) which I installed from day one instead of the bundled Wraith Stealth cooler as I was a bit worried about the temps. It was also done with the hope of maximising the boost clocks of the CPU by keeping it cooler. At idle to low usage scenarios, it sits at 44 degrees C and it climbs to 64 degrees under full load with an ambient temp of 32 degrees Celcius.The AMD Ryzen balanced option in the power profiles runs a little faster and is a little more power-hungry than the balanced profile and becomes available when the chipset driver is installed.I wish there were more affordable motherboards available for the launch of zen 2 but this processor is pretty decent for the price. I am planning to overclock later but I don't need the extra performance right now
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 9, 2019
